title: Top Torino Day Trips
text:
Torino, or Turin, is the biggest city in the Piemonte region of northern Italy. From Torino you can easily take day trips to see palaces and castles, wine regions, and other towns and cities. La Venaria Reale Picture: View of Garden. Progetto La Venaria Reale • La Venaria Reale: Baroque Savoy Palace and Gardens 
La Venaria Reale is a Baroque royal palace that was used as a Savoy residence in the 17th to 18th centuries, set in a huge park with gardens. La Venaria Reale is one of Northern Italy's UNESCO World Heritage Sites . The palace and gardens are closed on Mondays. Visiting hours vary by season but opening is usually at 10AM. 
Venaria is about 10 kilometers northwest of the city center. Take bus 11 or 72 to Venaria or City Sightseeing Torino Bus Line C from Piazza Castello. If you're coming by car, take the ring road and exit at Venaria. There's a large parking lot. The village of Venaria is a nice place to visit and has bars, shops, and places to eat. More » • Rivoli Castle 
Rivoli, about 10 miles west of Turin, has a castle that was a former Savoy residence. In the castle is a Museum of Contemporary Art. The castle and museum are open from 10-5, with later closing times on weekends, and closed on Mondays, January 1, May 1, and December 25. 
From Turin, take the metro departing from Porta Susa and get off at Paradiso stop, then take bus 36 to Rivoli. Rivoli Castle can also be reached by the City Sightseeing Torino Bus Line C from Piazza Castello (the same route that goes to La Venaria Reale). More » Martha Bakerjian, licensed to About.com • The City of Milan 
Spend the day in Milan visiting the stunning Gothic cathedral and Vittorio Emmanuele II shopping center, going to see the famous Last Supper painting by DaVinci (buy Last Supper Tickets from Select Italy ), or taking a tour of the Sforzesco Castle . 
Fast trains ( Frecciarossa ) make the trip from Torino to Milan in one hour. Buy train tickets from Select Italy . More » • Asti 
The city of Asti, about 18 miles east of Torino, is the center of the Asti sparkling wine producing region. Sections of the ancient city walls remain and there are several interesting churches and monuments in the medieval historic center. A synagogue and museum depict the history of the Jewish people in Asti, starting back as far as the 9th century. The third Sunday in September is the Palio di Asti , a bareback horse race dating from the 13th century. 
Regular trains to Asti take 35 to 40 minutes and the Metro line 6 (from Torino Lingotto ) takes about an hour. • Bra and Alba 
Bra is the birthplace of the Slow Food movement. There's a small historic center with artisan food shops and good places to eat, Baroque monuments, and a museum with historic and artistic exhibits. The Slow Cheese festival is held in Bra every 2 years in September. Alba is another foodie town, known for its truffle fairs held from mid-October through mid-November. It has a good market on Saturdays. 
To get to Bra, take metro line 4 (45 minutes from Torino Lingotto ). From there you can take a regular train to Alba. More » Vineyards in Piemonte's Langhe Wine Region. by James Martin 
If you have a car you can explore the beautiful Langhe wine region, southwest of Torino. As especially good time to go is fall when it's also truffle season. More » • Ivrea Carnevale 
If you're visiting Torino during carnevale , you may want to join in the unusual festivities at Ivrea that include a re-enactment of a medieval battle using oranges as ammunition. The battle is preceded by a parade with people in period costume. 
Trains to Ivrea take about one hour. The best way to travel between cities in Italy is usually by train. Here's what you need to know about riding the rails in Italy. Related Articles
